column4: Bulle: I think the manufacturers for the most part do not listen to Linux users
true true
its not that uncommon that it doesnt get installed nowadays, very few things still use inted
but ktalk was installed and not having a working inetd is a BAD think in that case

ktalk implies a kde program, right ? if so, its kubuntu that ist he culprit, as normal ubuntu is only gnome based, but yes, its a broken package imho, and ktalk should have the correct dependencies set for it
no I do not think ktalk is part of kde
well, i dont have any "ktalk" installed on my ubuntu install
so its not installed per default
I assure you I would not and did not install any talk daemon
just use dpkg-query to find out what package the file belongs to ?
so what package does the file belong to ?
well, something did
and it was not any official ubuntu package
yeah the installer
exactly where is this file ?
full path please
well, i run ubuntu, and i have a completely empty inetd.conf
so its most likely as un_operateur says, somethign added it there, dunno what
i bet un_operateur is very awayre of the fact
and what do you want him to do about it ?
it is a bug in the install process, so is there a place I can report it?
first find out if it is the install process that actualy did it
what else could have done it? I am not trying to argue so let's forget it  :)

as no one else seem to have that in their inetd.conf you should first find the bug, no one will do a thing about a bugreport that says "i found something in my inted.conf that i dont think shoudl be there"
